awd_titl_txt: NSF/MCB-BSF High-resolution mapping of the protein landscape in plant photosynthetic membranes
awd_abstract_narration:
Life on earth is fueled by photosynthesis, which converts sunlight into metabolic energy forms. In plants, photosynthetic energy conversion is realized by pigment-protein complexes that are harbored in highly specialized thylakoid membranes inside the chloroplasts. The dynamic response of the protein landscape in thylakoid membranes to unpredictable environmental changes (i.e. fluctuations in sunlight intensity by clouds, self-shading of leaves in wind) triggers photoprotective high-energy quenching (qE) that is essential for the survival of the plant. The project will map qE-induced protein landscape dynamics in thylakoid membranes with molecular resolution as a basis for understanding key photosynthetic functions. The intellectual merit of the proposed work is that it defines an innovative and complete pipeline of methods, ranging from state-of the art electron microscopy to coarse grain computer simulations, which will provide a quantitative understanding of photosynthetic light harvesting and electron transport. This pipeline will lead to urgently needed insights into dynamic structure-function relationships in thylakoid membranes. Furthermore, it is raising protein landscape analysis to a new level with unprecedented resolution to increase our in-depth understanding of photosynthetic energy conversion. The broader impact of the project is twofold:  First, it will provide hands-on research experience to undergraduate students from underrepresented groups, and establish a new computer-based teaching tool for a computational chemistry course. Second, social benefits of the proposed work are expected for the improvement of crop plants and biofuel prospects since it turns out that optimization and adjustment of the qE mechanisms by bioengineering could be a powerful tool to increase plant performances. 

To generate high-resolution protein maps of the thylakoid protein landscape as basis to provide mechanistic understanding for the qE-dependent regulation of light-harvesting and electron transport, three specific aims will be pursued. Aim #1: Establishing high-resolution protein maps for different qE states. Plants will be examined using electron microscopy and compositional analysis which will lead to detailed coarse grain thylakoid protein landscapes. Aim #2: Determine how qE-induced changes in protein landscapes impact light harvesting and photoprotective qE. Coarse grain protein maps of thylakoid membranes will be used to model photosynthetic light harvesting in order to interpret measured data. Aim #3: Determine how qE-triggered switches in protein landscapes control diffusion dependent electron transport. A dynamic protein landscape model for the entire thylakoid membrane will be developed that allows simulation of the whole photosynthetic electron transport to understand in vivo data. 

This collaborative US/Israel project is supported by the US National Science Foundation and the Israeli Binational Science Foundation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary: The protein building blocks for the photosynthetic conversion of sunlight into chemical energy equivalents fueling plant metabolism and life on earth are harbored in the highly specialized thylakoid membrane system inside chloroplasts. Over several decades, high-resolution structures of these photosynthetic building blocks became available leading to deep mechanistic insights how the structures of these proteins determine their function. In contrast to the excellent knowledge of structure-function relationship of individual protein complexes, our understanding about their structural and functional cooperation on the mesoscopic level is scarce. This project, for the first time, established a computer-assisted high-resolution complete protein landscape model of stacked thylakoid membranes in intact leaf tissues. The model is based on experimental data gathered from wildtype and mutant plants effected in their capability to regulate light harvesting. It was constructed by a multi-disciplinary approach combining state-of-the art electron microscopy, quantitative biology for all protein complexes, and coarse grain models based on Monte Carlo methods. All individual approaches were finetuned to gain the information required for the generation of the model. The project outcomes bring protein landscape analysis to a new level with unprecedented spatial resolution that is essential to understand light harvesting in photosynthetic membranes. Furthermore, a complete set of functional data about different aspects of photosynthetic light harvesting was collected during the project. At the same time, mathematical tools were developed describing light absorption, energy migration and conversion, and photoprotective energy dissipation in the mesoscopic energy landscapes. Based on these developments, the next step is a comprehensive structure-based understanding of photosynthetic energy conversion by a systematic comparison of experimental data on light-harvesting with computational analysis of energy migration and conversion in our protein landscapes. In conclusion, this multi-disciplinary project generated a complete pipeline for a unique holistic computational description of stacked grana membranes that can be employed for addressing mechanistic questions about photosynthetic energy conversion and its dynamics. 

 

Intellectual Merit:

The proposed work has defined a highly innovative and creative combination of methods ranging from state-of the art electron microscopy, ultrafast and steady state spectroscopy, quantitative biochemistry, to coarse grain computer simulations allowing for a quantitative understanding of photosynthetic light harvesting. The resulting protein landscape models provided urgently needed insights into dynamic structure-function relationships of thylakoid membranes on the mesoscopic scale. By mapping dynamic changes in large-scale protein reorganizations in stacked thylakoid membranes with molecular resolution and comparison with experimental data, the model unravels the impact of membrane alterations for light-harvesting and photoprotection. In addition, the use of mutant plants allows examination how competition by photoprotective high energy quenching works on the mesoscale. In this way, the project has closed a crucial gap by presenting a holistic protein landscape model allowing a mechanistic understanding how energy flows through the pigment network in stacked grana to photosystem II to drive photochemistry. We expect that that our approach will stimulate new research directions for understanding photosynthetic energy transformation by acknowledging the critical role of the protein landscape, a so far neglected aspect in photosynthesis research. 

 

 

Broader Impacts:

The project has provided hands-on research projects and training for five undergraduate students selected from underrepresented groups in STEM science, training and career development of four postdoctoral scholars, and one technician. Furthermore, after publication, the coarse-grain computer models that has been developed in this project will be released as open-source packages to extend the publicly available tools for simulating photosynthesis by adding the crucial mesoscopic structural level, a research area of growing interest. Social benefits of the proposed work are expected for improving crop plants and biofuel prospects because it turns out that tuning and adjustment of the energy migration and dissipation during photosynthetic light harvesting by bioengineering techniques could be a powerful tool to increase plant performances in more challenging environmental conditions. A better understanding of how mesoscopic dynamics determine central functions of photosynthetic energy conversion could energize new research directions for increasing the robustness and efficiency of crop plants and for exploring biofuel prospects that becomes relevant against the background of a rapidly changing global climate. In addition, our methodical developments in electron microscopy (cryo-scanning electron microscopy on freeze fractured leaf discs), quantification of thylakoid building blocks, and finetuning functional measurements (in vivo spectroscopy) is transferable to other plants and photosynthetic organism providing the photosynthesis community with a new methodical portfolio. In addition, our methodical platform developed paves the way for studying structure-function relationships in other biomembranes as well.
